p.s: The situation is quite strained because Ruth does not want to discuss.
She is trying to convince Walter, that he eats his eggs (l. 34).
She seems to be frustrated and worked up when she says: Walter, leave me alone! (l. 34).
Walter reacts angrily and feels marginalised (l. 23).

In the end of the extract Walter holds a dialogue and repeats what he said and how Ruth answered: Man say to his woman: I got me a dream.His woman say: Eat your eggs.Man say: I got to take hold of this here world, baby!And woman will say: Eat your eggs and go to work.Man say: I got to change my life, I'm choking to death, baby!And his woman say: Your eggs is getting cold! (ll. 35-38).
ThisThese statements make clear, that Walter is quite frustrated.
A little earlier he gave an example of how he thingsthinks Ruth is talking to Mama/Lena (ll. 18-23).
For Walter everything seems to be easier for Ruth than for him.
In his oppinionopinion Lena listens to [Ruth] more than she do [him] and Bennie (l. 19).
For Walter the world seems absolutely unfair.
On the other side Walter knows, that Ruth is tired of everything.[Walter], the boy, the way [they] live (l. 11).
He seems to feel with his wife.
In contrast he indirectly calls her good-for-nothing loud mouth (l. 5), because she talks to him.
Furthermore he thinks women do nearly understand nothing about the world (ll. 32f.).
Again he contradictcontradicts his own, because at the same time he saissays, that women know nothing and he needs for a woman to back him up (l. 16).
He realizes, that he is not able to do it on his own.
Also for realizing his dream, Walter needs help.
He needs money and friends or family to make his dream come true.
His problem is, that all the women in his family are not convinced of his dream of a liquor store.
Ruth reacts with a frawn (l. 26) when Walter tells her Bobo will help her with the shop.
